frame.name: Identity_scenario
frame.definition:
<def-root>An <fen>Instance</fen> of some <fen>Type</fen> is conceived of as having a distinct <fen>Identity</fen>. Its <fen>Identity</fen> persists across time and remains constant for an <fen>Instance</fen> despite arbitrary changes in other attributes of the <fen>Instance</fen>. Establishing <fen>Identity</fen> answers the question "which", and is often answered by saying that an <fen>Instance</fen> is the same or different from a previously mentioned instance (see Identicality), or by deictic reference ("that one"), etc.
<fen>Identity</fen> is not the same as appearance or name (if the <fen>Instance</fen> even has such), although these attributes of the <fen>Instance</fen> may be useful in establishing <fen>Identity</fen>. <fen>Identity</fen> can be established knowing the totality of the history of an <fen>Instance</fen>; however, this is impractical and usually proxies like name and appearance are used. For the <fen>Identity</fen> of humans, history sufficient to establish <fen>Identity</fen> can usually be satisfactorily established by documents associated with the person, often with information like appearance and name, though use of such documents leads to the problem of multiple identities, only one of which is considered legitimate or "true" in a given context. </def-root>

FE.name: Type
FE.definition:
<def-root>The kind of thing of which instances are under discussion.
<ex>Smithers works in a <t>different</t> <fex name="tp">office</fex> now</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Instance
FE.definition: <def-root>The instance of the <fen>Type</fen> that is currently under discussion.</def-root>

FE.name: Identity
FE.definition: <def-root>The property of an <fen>Instance</fen> that is defined as unique for each separate <fen>Instance</fen> of a <fen>Type</fen>.</def-root>
